title: Family presence during resuscitation
authors: Afzali Rubin, M; Svensson, TLG; Herling, SF; Jabre, P; Møller, AM

response.output:
What does letting family members watch a resuscitation (family presence during resuscitation, FPDR) do for them?

Key Messages
– FPDR may help relatives feel less scared and hurt after a resuscitation, but we are very uncertain about how much help it gives.
– FPDR probably does not change how long the resuscitation takes or how stressed the doctors and nurses feel.
– More well‑designed studies are needed to know for sure whether FPDR is helpful or not.

Introduction
What is family presence during resuscitation?  FPDR is when a relative or close friend is allowed to stay in the room while a patient is being revived.  The idea is that the family can see what is happening and may feel more involved in the care.

Why do people want to be there?  Many patients and relatives want to be part of the decision‑making process, even when a life‑saving emergency is happening.  Being present can give relatives a sense of control and may help them understand the situation.

What did we want to find out?  We wanted to know whether offering relatives the chance to stay during resuscitation changes how they feel afterwards.  We also wanted to see if it changes how the patient is treated, how long the resuscitation lasts, and how stressed the medical staff feel.

What did we do?  We looked for all studies that compared letting relatives stay during resuscitation with not letting them stay.  We then combined what those studies reported and judged how confident we could be in the results.

What did we find?
Study characteristics
We found two studies that met our criteria.  Together they included 595 adults, most of whom were women and aged between 19 and 78 years.  One study was done in France with emergency medical teams, and the other was a small pilot study in the United Kingdom’s emergency department.

Main results
PTSD symptoms
In the larger study, relatives who were allowed to stay during resuscitation had fewer signs of PTSD than those who were not allowed to stay.  Because the evidence is very uncertain, we say: FPDR may reduce PTSD symptoms.

Anxiety, depression and complicated grief
The same study also found that relatives who stayed during resuscitation reported less anxiety, less depression and less complicated grief after one year.  Again, the evidence is very uncertain, so we say: FPDR may reduce these feelings.

Resuscitation duration and staff stress
The French study measured how long the resuscitation lasted and how stressed the doctors and nurses felt.  It found no difference between the two groups.  Because the evidence is very uncertain, we say: FPDR may make little to no difference to how long the resuscitation takes or how stressed the staff feel.

Limitations of the evidence
We have little confidence in the evidence because the studies were small and had many problems that could affect the results.  The studies were not perfect, and the number of people involved was limited, so we are not sure how reliable the findings are.

How up to date is this evidence?
The evidence is up to date to March 2022.
